name: propylene production, from methanol-to-propylene conversion | ethylene | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28541/documentation

This dataset represents the production of propylene via Lurgi's methanol-to-propylene (MTP) process. Namely, this dataset covers the production of 1.00 kg of propylene as reference product, while gasoline (i.e., as C5-C10 hydrocarbons) and ethylene are also co-produced (1.08 and 0.08 kg, respectively) as by-products. This inventory is represented with an excess of electricity as valuable output due to the modularity of the auxiliary services used. Overall, the production of propylene from methanol is a net consumer of electricity.  The process includes, feedstock, materials, energy and registers all relevant direct emissions.;Light olefins are crucial building blocks for the chemicals and plastics sector and are predominantly generated through steam cracking of hydrocarbons. The annual production volume of ethylene and propylene are extremely high and constitutes them as the most highly produced petrochemicals. The high production volume of light olefins is driven by a high demand, which in 2007 amounted to 115 and 73 Mt for ethylene and propylene, respectively.;Notably, methanol may be used to cover part of the ethylene and propylene demand. Besides, such pathway may be appealing to decouple the production of light olefins from the petroleum feedstocks, e.g., naphtha.;In this dataset, Lurgi's MTP process is described, which represents the most efficient scheme for maximizing the production of propylene, and for retaining a low coking tendency, while maintaining a very low propane and by-products yield. In this technology, propylene is produced in two steps, where methanol is first converted to dimethyl ether (at almost equilibrium mixture), and subsequently converted to propylene using a ZSM-5 catalyst (zeolite-based) in a fixed-bed reactor. A typical MTP plant may produce, along with propylene, MTP-gasoline, MTP-liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and small quantities of ethylene.;References:;Olah, G.A. (2005), Beyond Oil and Gas: The Methanol Economy. Angewandte Chemie International Edition, 44: 2636-2639. https://doi.org/10.1002/anie.200462121;Bertau, M., Offermanns, H., Plass, L., Schmidt, F., & Wernicke, H. J. (Eds.). (2014). Methanol: the basic chemical and energy feedstock of the future (Vol. 1). Heidelberg: Springer.

The activity starts with the raw materials entering the methano-to-propylene facility.

The activity ends with the final products being ready for further processing or transportation at the production site gate. The dataset includes the consumption of raw materials and energy, estimated catalyst use, emissions to air and water from the process, as well as the infrastructure use.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This activity originates from literature data, for conversion of methanol to propylene (MTP) published in 2020 The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and not expected to change significantly over the next 5 years.;References:;Daniel F. Rodríguez-Vallejo, Gonzalo Guillén-Gosálbez, and Benoît Chachuat ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering 2020 8 (8), 3072-3081 DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b05516
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This inventory is modelled for China, where the coal-to- and methanol-to-propylene technology is an important technological pathway to produce propylene.;According to Lv et al (2021), in 2019, 24% of propylene produced in China was supplied from methanol conversion plants. ;This activity originates from literature data, based on robust process simulation, for the conversion of methanol to propylene (MTP). Since the specific technology is modelled, the inventory is not linked to any specific geographical region. The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and are, therefore, considered to be valid for the chosen geography.;References:;Daniel F. Rodríguez-Vallejo, Gonzalo Guillén-Gosálbez, and Benoît Chachuat ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering 2020 8 (8), 3072-3081 DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b05516;2021, Lin Lv, Guobao Song, Xinyue Zhao, Jingwen Chen, Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799;https://www.woodmac.com/news/can-chinas-cto-and-mto-industries-survive-the-threat-of-massive-steam-cracker-investment/, assessed in 2023-10-09.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In this dataset, the catalytic conversion of methanol to propylene is based on the work by Rodríguez-Vallejo et al. (2020). First, the methanol feedstock, before being fed into the dimethyl ether (DME) synthesis reactor, is pumped, and heated to the expected operating conditions. Namely, the reaction takes place at 300°C and 1.65 bar, attaining a 90% methanol equilibrium conversion that resembles typical industrial yields and conditions.;Subsequently, the reactor outlet, consisting of a DME and methanol mixture, is fed into the methanol-to-propylene (MTP) reactor, filled with a ZSM-5 catalyst. In the reactor, the mixture is converted mainly to olefins, such as (1) ethylene; (2) propylene; (3) C4 olefins, (4) C5 olefins; and (v) higher hydrocarbons, ranging from C6 to C10 (such as hexene(s), heptane(s), octenes, nonene(s), and decene(s)).;The MTP reactor operates at 425°C and 1.65 bar, that ensures the high methanol/DME conversion to propylene, while the overall reaction scheme is exothermic. The released heat from the latter exothermic reactor is used in a Rankine cycle to generate electricity, which is consumed internally. Any excess of generated electricity is considered as a valuable by-product.  ;The MTP reactor outlet is then cooled to 40°C, where an aqueous and organic phase is generated, and fed into a flash unit to remove the aqueous phase. The gaseous organic phase is pressurized in a three-stage compression train, with intermediate cooling, at 28.2 bar. The compressed stream is fed into a distillation column where a mixture of C4-C10 hydrocarbons is obtained at the bottom. The top stream consists of ethylene, propylene, and water, and thus, water is removed with a second flash unit prior to the purification and separation of ethylene-propylene. The water-free stream is, finally, fed into a second distillation column where polymer-grade ethylene and propylene are obtained at the top and bottom, respectively. The condenser of the second distillation unit operates at temperatures below ambient (ca. -21°C) and thus, a cooling cycle with a R134a working fluid was considered.;;;References:;Daniel F. Rodríguez-Vallejo, Gonzalo Guillén-Gosálbez, and Benoît Chachuat ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering 2020 8 (8), 3072-3081 DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b05516;Olah, G.A. (2005), Beyond Oil and Gas: The Methanol Economy. Angewandte Chemie International Edition, 44: 2636-2639. https://doi.org/10.1002/anie.200462121;Bertau, M., Offermanns, H., Plass, L., Schmidt, F., & Wernicke, H. J. (Eds.). (2014). Methanol: the basic chemical and energy feedstock of the future (Vol. 1). Heidelberg: Springer.

Main raw material for the production of light olefins. According to the operating rates of methanol-to- and coal-to-olefins plants in China, 60% of capacity is covered by coal-based methanol, according to https://infogram.com/methanol_asia_ctotable_october22-1ho16vod7o5yx4n, accessed 15-09-2023. The remaining 40% is covered by the methanol market.


Reference:
 Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.

exchanges.description:
Cooling requirements, at temperatures below ambient, for the production of propylene from methanol.

Calculated value, based on the aggregated cooling energy reported by Rodríguez-Vallejo et al. (2020). Namely, Rodríguez-Vallejo et al. (2020) reported cooling water and cooling below ambient conditions (at -25°C) as an aggregate of 9.49 MJ per kg propylene produced. The cooling energy at below ambient conditions was, here, re-calculated based on the stream table available at the thesis of Rodríguez-Vallejo (2021) and the work requirments reported by Luyben (2019). 

References: 
Rodríguez-Vallejo, Daniel F., Gonzalo Guillén-Gosálbez, and Benoît Chachuat. "What is the true cost of producing propylene from methanol? The role of externalities." ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering 8.8 (2020): 3072-3081.
Rodriguez Vallejo, Daniel. "Promoting sustainability in chemical process design using process modelling, environmental assessment and decision making." (2021).
Luyben, William L. "Refrigerant selection for different cryogenic temperatures." Computers & Chemical Engineering 126 (2019): 241-248.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value, based on the aggregated cooling energy reported by Rodríguez-Vallejo et al. (2020). Namely, Rodríguez-Vallejo et al. (2020) reported cooling water and cooling below ambient conditions (at -25°C) as an aggregate of 9.49 MJ per kg propylene produced. The cooling energy at below ambient conditions was, here, re-calculated based on the stream table available at the thesis of Rodríguez-Vallejo (2021) and the work by Luyben (2019). Hence, this allows the calculation of the energy removed from cooling water with a given temperature difference, 11°C.
References: 
Rodríguez-Vallejo, Daniel F., Gonzalo Guillén-Gosálbez, and Benoît Chachuat. "What is the true cost of producing propylene from methanol? The role of externalities." ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering 8.8 (2020): 3072-3081.
Rodriguez Vallejo, Daniel. "Promoting sustainability in chemical process design using process modelling, environmental assessment and decision making." (2021).
Luyben, William L. "Refrigerant selection for different cryogenic temperatures." Computers & Chemical Engineering 126 (2019): 241-248.
Calculated as a fraction of the input of water. For more details, refer to the mathematical relation and the parameters.
